reviewText: Although theXanadu - Original Soundtrack Albumwas a smash hit, with several Top Ten hits including Olivia-Newton John's #1 smash "Magic" (my favorite ONJ song of all), ELO's "All Over the World," the ONJ/Cliff Richard duet "Suddenly" (one of Cliff's few U.S. hits), and the title track (performed by ONJ and ELO), the 1980 movie was a box-office bomb.  It's a shame, because the movie, while fluffy, is a delightful pastiche to Hollywood musicals of yesteryear.  Gene Kelly is delightful in one of his last roles, and dances nimbly with ONJ to "Whenever You're Away From Me."  ONJ gets to do more tapping in the movie production-number version of the title track.  Not everything works:  the '40s - '80s contrast in the ONJ/Tubes number "Dancin'" doesn't work too well (perhaps the two versions should have been kept separate).  But on the whole, the movie is delightful escapist entertainment.This Magical Musical Edition features the DVD, with a photo gallery, a retrospective documentary (ONJ does not appear, and while Gene Kelly is deceased, there are no archival interviews with him either), and the original theatrical trailer.  The soundtrack CD is also included, although there are no bonus tracks.  If you already have the CD, buy thestandard DVD.

reviewText: A lot of people seem to describe this as one of those movies that are "so bad, it's good."  I cannot agree.This is a curiosity item only, in cinematic history.  From perhaps a time (pre-MTV), when everyone and anyone was hopped up on whatever the drug of choice was back then in Hollyweird.  I KNOW this is a "fantasy" film, but why'd they have to make it so bad?  Namely, by constantly undercutting/interrupting potentially interesting flashy/romantic effects sequences with extremely boring and overlong, badly written, directed, and acted segments, and lots of unnecessary and tasteless "camp?"  And with an uncomfortable and weird mixture of 40's "swing" with the beginnings of bad 80's "Reagan-era" pop/rock.This is "Saturday Night Fever" mixed with "Cats" mixed with your average early "music video" produced on bad mushrooms and/or too much caffeine, shown with a goofy cartoon not at the beginning of the film, but somewhere in the middle!  Not that it's all bad.  There are a lot of pretty colors, lots of interesting special effects (for its time), some catchy tunes (especially "Xanadu"), but overall it's just a total misfire on almost every other level.  Especially with the total lack of believable writing and "acting" that is universally awful, even from the legend Gene Kelly.  And long, overlong, unimaginative, laughable "real life" storyline scenes with acting performances which are sad to watch because this was evidently the script they were handed with and nobody objected.A shame in a way.  With a few re-writes, this could've been something special.  It does, but too rarely, capture a wild, visual/musical abandon, but it does little with the idea with way too much drab, plastic filler.  Olivia is about the only saving grace here, her striking beauty and angelic voice second to none, but alas, lost in all the muck and mud.  As are Gene Kelly's forced contributions, which are embarrassing at best.  The rest of the cast is totally forgettable and obviously talentless.  Even the semi-prog rock/pop band "Electric Light Orchestra" is wasted here.  And it appears that this was some sort of "showcase" for them.I had seen this originally when or shortly after it was released, and only recently saw it again on cable.  It's as out-of-touch in the final analysis, now, as it was back then.  Some applaud this for it's "up with people" spirit, but from my last viewing to my most recent, I find it strangely, and sadly, depressing.  Because for every good minute here, there are four or five or six bad ones the viewer must suffer through.  Unnecessarily, I think.I'd strongly recommend ANYONE actually considering buying this sight unseen, to forget all reviews, good or bad, and at least rent or try to catch it on cable first, before laying down actual money for this.  For all its flashiness, and some visual innovations, for its length there is really only about 10 minutes or so of half decent musical, romantic fluff fantasy visually acceptable material here.  That's a very poor ratio, even for supposedly movies so bad that they're "good."  You do the math.There is really only one bottom line "good" thing going about this overall mess.  Discerning viewers with taste who insist on watching this more than once will at least quickly get to know which long, tedious parts to fast forward through upon repeated viewings.

reviewText: One strong theme in the American arts is the idea of transformation of person. The New World has been envisioned as a place without an entrenched aristocracy, where people can leave behind a former self and begin anew. This theme, before reaching fruition in Xanadu in 1980, was exemplified in three works: Benjamin Franklin's The Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin, Horatio Alger's rags-to-riches tales, and F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Great Gatsby. This is refected primarily in two motifs: 1). the transformation of an abandoned roller skating rink into a vintage fin-de-decade 70s roller disco rink and 2). the recurring cartooned versions of certain characters, a literal transformation of self that is entirely controlled.Astonishingly, there is little in Xanadu to betray its 24-year gestation period. Whimsy, satire, and tart sympathy are kept in nimble balance throughout the gorgeous musical, and even if Gene Kelly's life defies the laws of logic, it has all the buoyant integrity of a Chagall painting. It has rightly been called, by amateur film critic Tim Edstrom, the most important film to reflect on issues of women's emancipation.In Xanadu, we also see the passing of the torch between Old Hollywood in the form of Gene Kelly and New Hollywood, brilliantly displayed in the form of Australian actress Olivia Newton-John.
summary: Xanadu: Fruition of a Great American Theme.

reviewText: Why is this movie so badly rated?* The acting:  Yes, some of the side parts are pedestrianly acted.  But the leads (Newton-John, Beck, Kelly) put in competent performances.  Acting grade when averaged:  B* The movie's concept:  Follow your dreams despite the harshness of reality.  Re-live your past upon the realization of age.  The concepts are presented without so much a hint of malice or irritability.  But more on presentation in a moment.  If anything, it's simple by today's standards.  In 1980, it must've been too much for ordinary audiences.  Concept grade:  A-* The movie's presentation:  In a word - "conceptual".  Roll with the concept and you'll be hooked from the start.  There is an innocent, organic, "real" feel to a movie that uses visual cues more often than dialogue to promote its point.  Case in point is the opening ~10 minutes.  An annoyed artist who feels pursuing his dreams is a waste of time takes a distinguished sketch and tears it up; the shreds floating down and, without explanation, causes these mystical painted figures to become alive -- the expressions on their faces is that of the joy of escaping a painted backdrop.  It's almost the perfect metaphor for life in general:  A soul released into the world...  The grade for presentation:  A-* The token tacky moment:  An inverse grade; every movie has one really cringe-inducing moment, and it's a matter of judging how infamous this moment affects the whole movie experience.  For me, said scene is the roller skating with the sync-clapping "extravaganza".  Yes, this is where some legitimate vomiting would be allowed.  Wonderfully choreographed, yes, and impeccable given the fantasy nature of the film, but it feels claustrophobic in spite of it all and it's also the sort of thing you would not want to see if you went to a skating rink for real.  Especially if someone sneezed at just the wrong moment.  Fantasy is surely more than a big roller skating rink, how much in 1980 was?  Mind you, this scene is the climax of the metaphor OF the roller skates, which is whimsical freedom.  Token tacky moment grade:  C.  (at least it isn't A, which for any other category would be an F...)* The songs:  A perfect fit for this movie; these songs hold up on their own extremely well and are, in a word, "enchanting".  Now ELO is not usually my "cup of tea", but their song "I'm Alive" is one of the most uplifting songs I've ever listened to.  Never mind Olivia's "Magic", which is more powerful than a chorus of Sirens...  A definite no-brainer, the grade for the songs:  A+* The special effects: Many were easy to achieve in 1980.  Not all were so easy, and in 2008 they look dated.  All effects do.  While not perfect, then or now, they do adequately convey the feel of innocence we all need more of in our lives.  Grade:  C+Overall rating:  B+All in all, I just can't understand why this movie is poorly rated.  Make your dreams or be a slave.  And the movie makes the point without being sarcastic, callous, or jaded.  The goal is success, not hate.It's a neglected gem.
summary: A neglected gem, ahead of its time: Xanadu is not a xanadud!

I can think of few movies that can take me back to warm summers, feathered- hair beauties, and great music of the then- dying decade of the seventies (if I recall, it was released in 1980). This movie somehow embraces new age kitch in a way that can only be described in a situation on NBC's "Friends"...Phoebe (Lisa Kudrow) when seeing Olivia onscreen in Joey's apartment: "Oooh, Xanadu!" Forget the guilty pleasure label and the critics, laugh with the movie, enjoy Olivia as the work of art she is, and just remember when cheese was pretty hot.

reviewText: Xanadu has gotten better with age but leaves a mixed impression. Gene Kelly was a nostalgic and welcome part of the doings, when he's actually an active part of a scene, not just a grinning bystander.  Overall, if it weren't for eye candy Olivia, a few decent songs and the special effects, Xanadu would be even less than it is.
